div.l: Helpe water water for goddes herte
This Carpynter oute of his slomer sterte
And harde one crie water as he were wood
And thought allas nowe commeth Noes flood
He set hym̄ vp͒ withoute wordes moo
And with his Axe he smote the corde two
He fell doun̄ to the flore and there a swoun̄ he lay
Vp͒ sterte hure Alisoıı̄un and Nicholay
And cried oute and harowe in the strete
The nyghtbours than̄ bothe smale and grete
In ronnen̄ for to gawren̄ on this man̄
That in swounyng lay bothe pale and wan̄
For with the fall he broken̄ had his Armes
But stonde he moste to his owne harmes
For when̄ he spake . he was anon̄ bore doun̄
Of hende Nicholas and Alisoun̄
They tolden̄ eủery man̄ that he was wood
He was agast so of Noes flood
Thrugh fantasie that of his vanyte
He bought hym̄ knedyng Tubbys thre
And had hem̄ hanged in the Rof a bove
And that he praide them̄ for goddis love
To sitten̄ in the Rof for companye
The folke gan̄ laughen̄ at his fantasye
Into the . Rof they kekyn̄ and they gape
And turned all his harmys vnto Iape
For what so that this Carpenter aunswerd
It was for nought . no man his reasoıı̄un herd
With othes grete he was so sworn̄ doun̄
That he was holden̄ wode thrugh all the toun̄
For eủery Clerke anon̄ right hilde with other
And seide the man̄ was wode my lef brother
And eủery wight gan̄ laughen at this strif
Thus swyved was the Carpenters wif
For all his kepyng and his Ielosie
And Absolou had kist hure nether ye
And Nicholas is scalded in the toute
My tale is don̄ . and god save all this route
Thus endeth the Millers tale Prologus p̉ropositi
Here begynneth the prologge of the Reve
